rule.name: zip code/postcode
rule.message: The term '\1 \2' is common for American English. Did you mean postcode?
rule.example: Please enter your zip code.
Zip codes are not always necessary.

rule.name: apartment/flat
rule.message: The word '\1' is common for American English. Did you mean flat?
rule.example: These apartments are expensive.
I just bought an apartment.

rule.message: The word '\1' is common for American English. (Band-Aid is a trademark.) Did you mean plaster?
rule.example: Where's the band-aid?

rule.message: The word '\1' is common for American English. (Band-Aid is a trademark.) Did you mean plasters?
rule.example: These band-aids are dirty.

rule.name: ground beef/minced beef
rule.message: The term '\1 \2' is common for American English. Did you mean minced \2?
rule.example: Do vegetarians eat ground beef?

rule.name: movie theater/cinema
rule.message: The term '\1 \2' is common for American English. Did you mean cinema?
rule.example: Let's go to a movie theater.
Movie theaters are popular, despite the new online movie streaming services.
Edward Norton – not appearing in a cinema near you.

rule.name: gotten/got
rule.message: In the UK, the word 'gotten' is not used. Did you mean got?
rule.example: He has gotten some food.
He's gotten up on the wrong side of bed.

rule.name: gas/petrol
rule.message: With the meaning of "gasoline", in British English is more common to use petrol.
rule.example: Natural gas.
More gas.

rule.name: License/Licence (noun)
rule.message: must be spelled with a "c" when used as a noun in British English. Use licence.
rule.example: Please show me your license.

rule.name: Licenses/Licences (noun)
rule.message: must be spelled with a "c" when used as a noun in British English. Use licences.
rule.example: Please show me your licenses.

rule.name: trunk/boot (of car)
rule.message: In the context of cars (automobiles), '' is American English. For British English use boot.
rule.example: The automobile has a small trunk.
Automobiles that have large trunks are usually expensive.
Trunks on some automobiles are at the front.
This Volkswagen has a large trunk.
Volkswagens and Chryslers usually have large trunks.
The elephant's trunk is long.
This tree trunk is large.
The trunks of some trees were damaged during the storm.
The arterial trunks of some rivers are ...
Trunks (swimming) of various colours are available from ...
If the electrical trunking on the car is ...
Put the trunk into the car boot.
The car boot contained trunks of many colours.
The car boots contained trunks of many sizes.
Put these items into the boot of the car: trunk, table, chair, kitchen sink.
Put the trunks into the boot of the car.
The lace on this boot is frayed.
The car boot contained a trunk and a ...
The car's boot contained a trunk and a ...
The trunks were in our car’s boot.
The boot of this Volkswagen contains a large trunk.
The boots of Volkswagens are sufficiently large to contain 2 or 3 trunks.
The trunk was in the Ford.
Mr Ford has a large blue trunk.
The trunk was on the back seat of the Ford.
The abandoned car contained a stolen trunk.
The Chrysler's boot contained a trunk and a ...
Some cars' boots can contain trunks of enormous size.

rule.name: air plane/aeroplane
rule.message: The term '\1 \2' is common for American English. For British English use aeroplane.
rule.example: This air plane is very quiet.
These air planes can fly for 12 hours when they are fully loaded with fuel.
This aeroplane is very quiet.

rule.name: 1-liter/1-litre
rule.message: The word '' is an adjective (SI unit of measurement), but the spelling is not correct British English.
rule.example: Use a 6-millimeter bolt.
Use a 6-millimetre bolt.
Do not find incorrect English: use a 10-millimeters bolt.
The 4.6-centigram difference is not a problem.
Use a 10-meter rope.
Also find typographic errors: a 5.7.8-femtoliter difference is not important.

rule.message: Oxford Manual of Style, 2002, gives 'gram' as the preferred spelling of these: gram, kilogram, and other units of measurement. Also, UK Weights and Measures Act 1985, section 92 shows that both 'gram' and 'gramme' are permitted in British English, and this spelling is applicable to other units that are compounds of 'gram'. Use .
rule.example: Use 3 milligrammes of surfactant.
Use 3 milligrams of surfactant.
The television programme is scheduled for 17:00.
If the distance is less than 2 millimeters, ...
A 6-gramme force is sufficient.
The weight must be less than 1 gramme.
The weight must be more than 20 kilogrammes.
One yottagramme is a lotta grams!
'Centigrammes' is an alternative spelling of 'centigrams'.
Add 2 KILOgrammes of the powder.
Did you read "The Teragramme Terror from Tangiers"? I think it's a good book.

rule.message: Oxford Manual of Style, 2002, gives 'gram' as the preferred spelling of these: gram, kilogram, and other units of measurement. Also, UK Weights and Measures Act 1985, section 92 shows that both 'gram' and 'gramme' are permitted in British English, and this spelling is applicable to other units that are compounds of 'gram'. Use .
rule.example: A 6-gramme force is sufficient.
A 6-gram force is sufficient.
Use a five-kilogramme weight.
A 10-microgramme difference is not sufficient.
A 5-yoctogramme error is not important.

rule.message: Oxford English Dictionary gives 'iz' as the preferred spelling of this word. Use .
rule.example: This has been an automatised conversion.
Visualisation methods are useful for complex tasks.

rule.name: Oxford spelling of nouns (~ization not ~isation)
rule.message: If there is a suggestion, you should use the Oxford spelling ''.
rule.example: The word 'organisation' is not the Oxford spelling.
The word 'organisations' is not the Oxford spelling.
The word 'organization' is the Oxford spelling.
The word 'organizations' is the Oxford spelling.
'Americanisation' is NNP.
'Americanisations' is NNPS.

Most of the surviving paperwork, up until 1986, for successful naturalisations is now held at The National Archives (www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/help-with-your-research/research-guides/naturalisation-british-citizenship/).
'Demutualisations: LT gives a spelling warning for demutualizations. BUT LT also suggests the Oxford spelling although the suggestion uses suppress_misspelled="yes". Why?
These words are always spelled with ~isation: improvisation/improvisations
de-energisations has no postag.

rule.name: Oxford spelling of verbs (~ize not ~ise)
rule.message: If there is a suggestion, you should use the Oxford spelling ''.
rule.example: The verb 'organise' is not the Oxford spelling.
Who usually organises the meetings?
Who organised the meeting?
The basic organising principles...
The word 'organize' is the Oxford spelling.

Keep this list of ~ise only verbs as a fail-safe test: abscise, advertise, advise, affranchise, alias [aliased], appraise, arise, braise, bruise, chastise, circumcise, comprise, compromise, counterpoise, cruise, demise, despise, devise, disenfranchise, disfranchise, disguise, dispraise, enfranchise, equipoise, excise, exercise, franchise, fundraise, improvise, incise, liaise, merchandise, misadvise, miscategorise, misraise, mortise, noise, outraise, overexercise, overpraise, overpromise, poise, porpoise [aviation slang], practise, praise, premise, previse, promise, raise, readvertise, readvise, rearise, reappraise, reprise, repromise, re-raise, reraise, revise, rise, supervise, surmise, surprise, televise, trellis [VBZ = trellises], underpraise, upraise, uprise, wise
The word 'otherwise' is not a verb.
These rare/obsolete ~ise-only verbs have no postag: annalise, bepraise, debruise, disseise, grandise, grise, hoise, marmalise, misprise, remise, re-rise, rerise, seise, sensibilise, unpromise,
recentralise is not found because suppress_misspelled="yes". 'Recentralize' has no pos.
